supportDesc.condition: A pillar-stone bearing both Latin and ogham inscriptions which seems to be 20 cm shorter today than when its measurements were first recorded (Smirke et al., 1861, 179). The two Latin inscriptions are both complete and the ogham inscription is also legible and complete (Okasha 1993, 106). At some point during 1861 or 1862, however, black paint was rather inaccurately applied to the letters of the inscriptions (Okasha 1993, 106). Okasha observed that the painted letters are clearly legible but the original texts are probably rather deteriorated (1993, 106).

layoutDesc.layout: The ogham inscription (1) reads vertically upwards on the two angles of the front face of the stone (1993, 106). The first part of the ogham inscription is incised on the upper part of the edge between the face and the right-hand side of the stone (1993, 106). The second part of the ogham text is incised on the upper part of the edge between the face and the left-hand side of the stone, and extends on to the edge between the face and the left-hand side of the stone. (1993, 106). There are two Latin inscriptions, one on the front and the other on the back of the stone: both inscriptions face left and read downwards. The Latin inscription on the front of the stone (2) consists of two lines and the Latin inscription on the back of the stone (3) is incised in one line (Okasha 1993, 103).

handDesc.handNote: Macalister described the ogham inscription as pocked in rather broad scores (1945, 468).

The two Latin inscriptions are set without panels or framing-lines and are written in a predominantly capital script(1993, 103). Macalister noted that in the Latin inscription on the front face of the stone (2), the Q is of half-uncial shape and in the inscription on the other face of the stone (3) the G is of the sickle shape, the R is half-uncial, and the N of the H shape (1945, 469). The letters for the inscription on the front of the stone (2) measure between 8 to 11 cm in height (Okasha 1993, 103). The letters for the inscription on the back of the stone (3) are between 12 to 15 cm in height (Okasha 1993, 103).

history.provenance: Formerly used as a footbridge over a local stream, the stone was later removed to a farmyard in Fardel where it served as a ring-post for a shed until 1861 when Captain Pode, the owner of the farm, presented the stone to the British Museum. The stone was first mentioned in 1861 by Smirke and later by Brash in 1869.

div.p: Ogham (1): '[the stone] of Safaqqucus, the son of Qicus'
Latin (2): '[the stone] of Fanonus, son of Rinus' or, alternatively, '[the stone] of Fanonus [son] of Maqivirinus' (Okasha 1993, 106).

Macalister maintained that the three inscriptions represent as many different appropriations of the stone and that there is no connexion between them (1945, 469). For the first of the Latin inscriptions (2), the name FANONI is Celtic and a similiar name, FANNVCI, occurs on a stone from Stackpole Elidyr Wales (Okasha 1993, 106). Additionally, the name MAQVIRINI would be Primitive Irish, but the name RINI would be of unknown origin (Okasha 1993, 106). Concerning the name, SAGRANVI, specified in the second Latin inscription (3), Okasha noted that the exact form of this name remains uncertain (1993, 106). Regarding the names mentioned in the ogham inscriptions, the MAQ- would indicate a Primitive Irish name while QICI and SAFAQQUCI are probably Celtic (Okasha 1993, 107). Furthermore, the phrase MAQI QIC occurs on an Irish ogham stone from Ballyvooney (Okasha 1993, 107). Okasha determined that based on the evidence both of the ogham texts and of the Irish nature of [the] texts...this stone is likely to date from the fifth or sixth century to the eighth century (1993, 107).
